levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 2s from 0 to 20 using pairs of objects as concrete support, with a number line for reference.
levels.example_task: Place cubes in pairs. Count the total as you add each pair: 2, 4, 6... Continue to 20.
common_errors: Reverting to counting in 1s after 10
Counting in 2s starting from 1 (1, 3, 5...) instead of 0

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting in 2s, 3s and 5s from 0 using a hundred square with multiples highlighted, forwards and backwards.
levels.example_task: Count in 3s from 0 to 30 using the hundred square.
common_errors: Losing count when crossing decade boundaries in 3s (e.g. saying 18, 20 instead of 18, 21)
Adding 2 or 5 instead of 3 when switching between sequences

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 2s, 3s and 5s from 0 or any given multiple, forwards and backwards, without support.
levels.example_task: Start at 15. Count in 3s to 30. Then count backwards in 5s from 45 to 10.
common_errors: Needing to start from 0 to reach the given starting point
Counting backwards in 3s is significantly harder than forwards (e.g. 21, 19 instead of 21, 18)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using skip-counting knowledge to solve problems and explain patterns.
levels.example_task: Is 25 a number you say when counting in 3s from 0? How can you check?
levels.example_response: No. I can count in 3s: 0, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27. I skip 25, so it is not a multiple of 3.
common_errors: Guessing 'yes' because 25 is in the 5 times table and confusing the sequences
Being unable to systematically check beyond reciting the whole sequence

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building two-digit numbers using Dienes ten-sticks and unit cubes on a place value mat (T | O).
levels.example_task: Build the number 45 using Dienes blocks. How many tens? How many ones?
levels.example_response: 4 tens and 5 ones. 4 ten-sticks and 5 unit cubes.
common_errors: Using 45 unit cubes instead of tens and ones
Saying '4 and 5' without identifying them as tens and ones

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Partitioning two-digit numbers into tens and ones using arrow cards or pictorial representations, including numbers with 0 ones.
levels.example_task: Partition 60 into tens and ones. What does the 0 mean?
levels.example_response: 60 = 60 + 0. There are 6 tens and 0 ones. The 0 means there are no ones.
common_errors: Saying 60 is '6' (reading only the tens digit)
Not understanding why a 0 is needed in the ones place

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Partitioning any two-digit number into tens and ones fluently, and using flexible partitioning.
levels.example_task: Partition 47 in two different ways.
common_errors: Writing 47 = 4 + 7 (face values instead of place values)
Only knowing the standard partition and being unable to partition flexibly

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining what happens to the tens and ones digits when 10 is added to or subtracted from a two-digit number.
levels.example_task: I have 38. I add 10. What happens to the tens digit and the ones digit? Why?
levels.example_response: 38 + 10 = 48. The tens digit goes from 3 to 4 because I added one more ten. The ones digit stays at 8 because I did not add any ones.
common_errors: Saying both digits change when 10 is added
Explaining that '38 becomes 48' without reference to the place value structure

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two numbers up to 20 using concrete objects to determine which is greater, with verbal comparison only.
levels.example_task: Which is more, 8 or 13? Show me with cubes.
levels.example_response: 13 is more than 8. My tower of 13 cubes is taller than my tower of 8 cubes.
common_errors: Comparing by the look of the digits rather than the quantity (e.g. thinking 8 is more because 8 looks bigger than 1 or 3)
Confusing 'greater' with 'bigger in size'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the < and > symbols to compare two-digit numbers, with a number line or hundred square for support.
levels.example_task: Write the correct symbol: 34 ? 28. Use < or >.
levels.example_response: 34 > 28. 34 is greater than 28.
common_errors: Writing 34 < 28 (reversing the symbol)
Not knowing which way the symbol points (the open end faces the larger number)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using <, > and = to compare numbers to 100 fluently, and ordering sets of numbers from smallest to largest.
levels.example_task: Put these numbers in order from smallest to largest: 67, 76, 49, 94. Use < to connect them.
common_errors: Ordering by ones digit: putting 49 after 67 because 9 > 7
Confusing 67 and 76 (tens and ones digits swapped)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recalling addition bonds to 10 using a ten frame and counters.
levels.example_task: Put 6 counters on the ten frame. How many empty spaces? What bond to 10 does this show?
levels.example_response: 4 empty spaces. 6 + 4 = 10.
common_errors: Miscounting the empty spaces (saying 3 or 5 instead of 4)
Knowing the addition bond but not the subtraction inverse (10 – 6 = 4)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Instant recall of all bonds to 20 without concrete support, including related subtraction facts.
levels.example_task: What is 8 + 7? What is 15 – 8?
common_errors: Needing to count on rather than recalling instantly
Knowing the addition fact but not the subtraction inverse

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Deriving facts to 100 from known bonds to 10 and 20 using place value reasoning.
levels.example_task: You know 6 + 4 = 10. What is 60 + 40? What is 56 + 4?
common_errors: Not connecting the known bond (6 + 4 = 10) to the derived fact (60 + 40 = 100)
Computing 56 + 4 by counting on rather than using the bond

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using known facts to check addition and subtraction by adding numbers in a different order.
levels.example_task: Is this correct: 37 + 25 = 62? Check by adding in a different order.
levels.example_response: Check: 25 + 37 = 25 + 30 + 7 = 55 + 7 = 62. Yes, it is correct.
common_errors: Checking by repeating the same calculation rather than using a different method
Not understanding why adding in a different order is a valid check

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding a one-digit number to a two-digit number without crossing 10, using Dienes blocks.
levels.example_task: Use Dienes blocks to work out 34 + 5.
levels.example_response: 34 + 5 = 39. I kept the 3 tens and added 5 ones to the 4 ones to get 9 ones.
common_errors: Adding 5 to the tens digit instead of the ones (34 + 5 = 84)
Getting 39 correct but unable to explain using place value

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting two-digit numbers and ones, tens, or two-digit numbers using a number line, including crossing tens boundaries.
levels.example_task: Work out 47 + 26 using a number line.
levels.example_response: Start at 47. Jump 20 to get 67. Jump 6 to get 73. 47 + 26 = 73.
common_errors: Miscounting jumps across the tens boundary (47 + 6 = 52 instead of 53)
Adding tens and ones separately but forgetting to combine (40 + 20 = 60, 7 + 6 = 13, then writing 6013 instead of 73)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting combinations of two-digit numbers using efficient mental or recorded methods, and solving word problems.
levels.example_task: There are 38 children in one class and 27 in another. How many altogether? Show your method.
common_errors: Column misalignment when recording in columns (putting 8 under 2 instead of under 7)
Forgetting to carry when 8 + 7 = 15 (writing 5 but not carrying the 1 ten)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Demonstrating commutativity with concrete objects: showing that 3 + 5 gives the same total as 5 + 3.
levels.example_task: Put 3 red cubes and 5 blue cubes together. Count the total. Now put 5 blue cubes and 3 red cubes together. Is the total the same?
levels.example_response: 3 + 5 = 8. 5 + 3 = 8. Yes, the total is the same both times.
common_errors: Recounting both groups from scratch rather than recognising the total must be the same
Believing the answer might be different if the order changes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using commutativity to check addition calculations and recognising that subtraction is not commutative.
levels.example_task: You worked out 14 + 8 = 22. How can you check this using commutativity? Does the same trick work for 14 – 8?
levels.example_response: Check: 8 + 14 = 22. Yes, it matches. No, 14 – 8 = 6 but 8 – 14 is not 6, so subtraction is not commutative.
common_errors: Thinking subtraction is also commutative (8 – 14 = 6)
Checking by repeating the same calculation rather than swapping the order

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using commutativity and associativity to add three numbers efficiently by choosing the easiest pair first.
levels.example_task: Work out 7 + 8 + 3. Which two numbers would you add first to make it easier? Why?
levels.example_response: Add 7 + 3 = 10 first, then 10 + 8 = 18. This is easier because 7 + 3 makes a number bond to 10.
common_errors: Always adding left to right without considering easier combinations
Not recognising number bonds within the three addends

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using a bar model to see that the same three numbers make one addition and two subtractions.
levels.example_task: The bar model shows: whole = 12, parts = 5 and 7. Write an addition and a subtraction using these numbers.
common_errors: Writing 5 – 7 = 12 (subtracting the wrong way)
Only writing one fact when the bar model gives four related facts

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the inverse relationship to check a calculation: adding to check subtraction and subtracting to check addition.
levels.example_task: You think 15 – 9 = 6. Check it using addition.
levels.example_response: Check: 6 + 9 = 15. Yes, it is correct.
common_errors: Checking by repeating 15 – 9 rather than using the inverse
Adding 15 + 9 instead of 6 + 9

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using the inverse to solve missing number problems and explain why the strategy works.
levels.example_task: Find the missing number: ? – 8 = 13. Explain how you found it.
levels.example_response: The missing number is 21. I used the inverse: 13 + 8 = 21. This works because if I take 8 away from the mystery number and get 13, then putting the 8 back must give me the mystery number.
common_errors: Computing 8 – 13 or 13 – 8 instead of 13 + 8
Getting the correct answer but unable to explain why the inverse method works

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 2s, 5s and 10s using concrete groups and connecting to the matching times table fact.
levels.example_task: Make 4 groups of 5 cubes. Count in 5s to find the total. What times table fact does this show?
common_errors: Counting in 5s correctly but not connecting to 4 × 5 = 20
Making groups of different sizes (not all exactly 5)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling multiplication facts for the 2, 5 and 10 times tables and connecting to division facts.
levels.example_task: What is 7 × 2? What is 14 ÷ 2?
common_errors: Confusing × with + (saying 7 × 2 = 9 instead of 14)
Knowing the multiplication fact but not the related division fact

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all multiplication and division facts for 2, 5 and 10 times tables, applied in context.
levels.example_task: Stickers come in packs of 5. I need 35 stickers. How many packs do I need?
levels.example_response: 35 ÷ 5 = 7. I need 7 packs.
common_errors: Knowing 7 × 5 = 35 but not recognising the problem requires division
Counting up in 5s to 35 rather than recalling the fact directly

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining connections between the 2, 5 and 10 times tables and using known facts to derive unknown ones.
levels.example_task: If you know 6 × 5 = 30, how can you work out 6 × 10?
levels.example_response: 6 × 10 = 60. I know this because 10 is double 5, so 6 × 10 is double 6 × 5. Double 30 is 60.
common_errors: Not seeing the doubling relationship between the 5 and 10 times tables
Knowing both facts by rote but unable to explain the connection

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Writing a multiplication statement from a concrete arrangement of equal groups.
levels.example_task: There are 3 plates with 2 biscuits on each. Write a multiplication to show this.
common_errors: Writing 2 × 3 = 6 (correct answer but reversed understanding of 'groups of')
Writing an addition instead: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 (valid but not using ×)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Writing both multiplication and division statements from arrays and equal group contexts.
levels.example_task: Look at this array: 4 rows of 5 dots. Write a multiplication and a division for it.
common_errors: Writing the division backwards: 5 ÷ 20 instead of 20 ÷ 5
Not recognising that the array shows two multiplication facts (4 × 5 and 5 × 4)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Writing multiplication and division statements from word problems and interpreting statements in context.
levels.example_task: Write a number sentence: 'There are 30 children sitting at 5 tables with the same number at each table. How many at each table?'
levels.example_response: 30 ÷ 5 = 6. There are 6 children at each table.
common_errors: Writing 5 × 30 instead of 30 ÷ 5 (not identifying this as division)
Confusing the ÷ symbol with the × symbol

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using an array to show that multiplication gives the same answer when the groups are swapped.
levels.example_task: Make a 3 × 4 array with counters. Now turn it sideways to make a 4 × 3 array. Is the total the same?
levels.example_response: Yes. 3 × 4 = 12 and 4 × 3 = 12. Turning the array does not change the number of counters.
common_errors: Recounting the turned array instead of recognising the total is unchanged
Not understanding why turning the array swaps the multiplication

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying commutativity to choose the easier order for a multiplication and recognising division is not commutative.
levels.example_task: Which is easier to work out: 2 × 9 or 9 × 2? Does the same thing work for division: is 12 ÷ 3 the same as 3 ÷ 12?
levels.example_response: 2 × 9 and 9 × 2 both equal 18 — I can do whichever is easier. But 12 ÷ 3 = 4 and 3 ÷ 12 does not give 4, so division is not the same both ways.
common_errors: Thinking division is commutative (saying 3 ÷ 12 = 4)
Not choosing the easier order when computing (always going left to right)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Explaining why multiplication is commutative using the language of groups, and explaining why division is not.
levels.example_task: Explain why 5 × 3 = 3 × 5 but 15 ÷ 3 does not equal 3 ÷ 15.
levels.example_response: 5 groups of 3 and 3 groups of 5 both give 15 objects — the array is the same, just turned. But sharing 15 among 3 gives 5 each, while sharing 3 among 15 gives less than 1 each. The answers are different.
common_errors: Saying 'it just is' without using groups or arrays to explain
Confusing the explanation for commutativity with the explanation for associativity

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Determining whether a small number (up to 10) is odd or even by sharing objects into two equal groups.
levels.example_task: Take 7 cubes. Can you share them equally into two groups? Is 7 odd or even?
levels.example_response: No, I get 3 and 4 — one group has 1 more. 7 is odd because it cannot be shared equally into 2 groups.
common_errors: Saying 7 is even because 'it's a big number'
Not realising that 1 left over means the number is odd

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying whether any number up to 20 is odd or even by checking the ones digit, using a number line or hundred square for support.
levels.example_task: Is 16 odd or even? Is 19 odd or even? How do you know?
levels.example_response: 16 is even because it ends in 6. 19 is odd because it ends in 9.
common_errors: Checking by pairing objects even for larger numbers (slow and error-prone)
Confusing the tens digit with the ones digit when deciding

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying any number up to 100 as odd or even instantly, and explaining the rule using the ones digit.
levels.example_task: Is 74 odd or even? Is 83 odd or even? Explain the rule.
levels.example_response: 74 is even because it ends in 4. 83 is odd because it ends in 3. The rule is: if the ones digit is 0, 2, 4, 6 or 8 it is even; if it is 1, 3, 5, 7 or 9 it is odd.
common_errors: Not knowing the rule and needing to count in 2s from 0 to check
Saying 74 is 'odd' because 7 is odd (checking the tens digit)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding one half and one quarter of a small quantity by physically sharing objects equally.
levels.example_task: Find half of 10 by sharing 10 counters equally between 2 plates. Find a quarter of 8 by sharing between 4 plates.
levels.example_response: Half of 10 is 5 (each plate gets 5). A quarter of 8 is 2 (each plate gets 2).
common_errors: Sharing between the wrong number of groups (sharing between 4 when finding a half)
Sharing unequally and not noticing

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding 1/3, 1/4, 2/4 and 3/4 of quantities using sharing or by finding the unit fraction first then multiplying.
levels.example_task: Find 3/4 of 12.
levels.example_response: First find 1/4 of 12 = 3. Then 3/4 = 3 × 3 = 9. So 3/4 of 12 is 9.
common_errors: Finding 1/4 correctly but not knowing how to get to 3/4
Dividing by 3 instead of 4 to find a quarter (1/4 of 12 = 4 instead of 3)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding unit and non-unit fractions of quantities and lengths, and counting in fractions on a number line.
levels.example_task: Count in quarters from 0 to 2 on the number line: 0, 1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 1, ... What is 1/3 of 18?
common_errors: Not knowing that 4/4 = 1 whole, so stopping at 3/4 and jumping to 1
Confusing 1/3 with 1/4 when computing fractions of quantities

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing folded paper strips to see that 1/2 and 2/4 cover the same area.
levels.example_task: Fold one strip in half and shade one part. Fold another strip in quarters and shade two parts. Compare them — are they the same?
levels.example_response: Yes, the shaded parts are the same size. 1/2 and 2/4 are the same amount.
common_errors: Saying they are different because '1 is not the same as 2'
Folding unevenly so the comparison is not accurate

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recognising 2/4 = 1/2 on a number line and using fraction walls to verify the equivalence.
levels.example_task: On the fraction wall, which fraction is the same as 1/2? Point to where 1/2 and 2/4 are on the number line.
levels.example_response: 2/4 is the same as 1/2. They are both at the same point on the number line, exactly halfway between 0 and 1.
common_errors: Placing 2/4 at a different point from 1/2 on the number line
Thinking 2/4 means '2 and 4' rather than '2 out of 4'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Explaining why 2/4 = 1/2 and recognising that equivalent fractions name the same value.
levels.example_task: Explain to a friend why 2/4 and 1/2 are the same.
levels.example_response: If you cut something into 4 equal parts and take 2, you have taken exactly half. 2 out of 4 is the same proportion as 1 out of 2.
common_errors: Knowing the fact by rote ('Miss told us') without understanding why
Thinking all fractions with a 2 on top are equal to 1/2

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Measuring the length of objects using a ruler, aligning the object with 0 and reading the end mark, for objects shorter than 30 cm.
levels.example_task: Measure the length of this pencil using a ruler. Start at 0.
levels.example_response: The pencil is 12 cm long.
common_errors: Starting from 1 on the ruler instead of 0
Reading the wrong number because the end of the pencil is between two marks

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Choosing and using appropriate standard units (m/cm, kg/g, °C, l/ml) and reading scales with labelled divisions.
levels.example_task: Would you measure the length of the classroom in cm or m? Read the temperature on this thermometer. [Shows 18°C]
levels.example_response: I would use metres for the classroom because it is very long. The thermometer shows 18°C.
common_errors: Choosing centimetres for very long objects or metres for small objects
Misreading the thermometer scale (reading 16°C or 20°C instead of 18°C)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Measuring length, mass, temperature and capacity with standard units, reading scales where not every division is labelled.
levels.example_task: This weighing scale is labelled 0, 100g, 200g, 300g with 5 marks between each label. What does each small mark represent? Read the mass shown. [Arrow points to 3rd mark after 200g]
levels.example_response: Each small mark represents 20g. The mass is 260g.
common_errors: Assuming each small mark is 1g (reading 203g instead of 260g)
Not working out the value of each interval before reading

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising all UK coins and notes by name and value, and using the £ and p symbols with whole amounts.
levels.example_task: This costs 35p. Write the price using the p symbol. This costs 2 pounds. Write it using the £ symbol.
common_errors: Writing £35p (using both symbols together)
Confusing p and £ (writing p2 instead of £2)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Making amounts using different combinations of coins and finding how many different ways to make a given amount.
levels.example_task: Make 30p using exactly 4 coins. Can you find a different way?
levels.example_response: 20p + 5p + 3p + 2p = 30p. Another way: 10p + 10p + 5p + 5p = 30p.
common_errors: Using the wrong number of coins
Not finding different combinations because they always start with the largest coin

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving money problems involving making amounts, adding prices and giving change.
levels.example_task: A toy costs 45p. You pay with a 50p coin. How much change do you get?
levels.example_response: 50p – 45p = 5p. I get 5p change.
common_errors: Counting up from 45 to 50 correctly but struggling with larger amounts
Computing 50 – 45 by column subtraction and making a borrowing error

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading o'clock and half past times on an analogue clock (consolidating Year 1).
levels.example_task: What time does this clock show? [Shows 9 o'clock, then half past 2]
levels.example_response: 9 o'clock. Half past 2.
common_errors: Reading half past 2 as 'half past 3' (reading the number the hour hand is moving towards)
Confusing the hour and minute hands

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading times to five-minute intervals using the minute hand position: 5 past, 10 past, quarter past, 20 past, 25 past, half past.
levels.example_task: What time does this clock show? [Minute hand at 3, hour hand between 7 and 8]
levels.example_response: Quarter past 7. The minute hand is at 3, which means 15 minutes past.
common_errors: Reading 'quarter past' as '3 o'clock' (reading the minute hand number as hours)
Not connecting the minute hand position (at 3) to 15 minutes

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading any time to five minutes on an analogue clock, including 'to' times (quarter to, 10 to, 5 to), and drawing clock hands.
levels.example_task: What time does this clock show? [10 minutes to 6] Draw a clock showing quarter to 9.
levels.example_response: 10 to 6. The minute hand is at 10, which means 50 minutes past or 10 minutes to the next hour. [Draws minute hand at 9, hour hand just before 9]
common_errors: Confusing 'to' and 'past' times (calling 10 to 6 '10 past 5')
Drawing the hour hand pointing exactly at 9 for quarter to 9 instead of just before 9

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting the number of sides and corners (vertices) of common 2-D shapes by tracing with a finger.
levels.example_task: Trace around this shape. How many sides does it have? How many corners?
levels.example_response: It has 4 sides and 4 corners. It is a rectangle.
common_errors: Counting a side twice or missing a side
Confusing 'sides' and 'corners' — counting corners when asked for sides

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying and comparing 2-D shapes by their properties (number of sides, vertices, right angles), including non-standard orientations.
levels.example_task: How are a square and a rectangle similar? How are they different?
levels.example_response: Both have 4 sides and 4 corners with right angles. A square has all sides the same length but a rectangle has 2 long sides and 2 short sides.
common_errors: Saying 'squares and rectangles are completely different shapes'
Not recognising a square as a special type of rectangle

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Sorting 2-D shapes by properties including line symmetry, and identifying shapes from a description of properties.
levels.example_task: I am thinking of a shape. It has 3 sides, 3 corners and 1 line of symmetry. Draw it.
levels.example_response: An isosceles triangle. [Draws a triangle with a vertical line of symmetry — two sides the same length]
common_errors: Drawing an equilateral triangle (3 lines of symmetry, not 1)
Not knowing how to check for a line of symmetry

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting the faces of common 3-D shapes by handling them and touching each face.
levels.example_task: Pick up this cuboid. Touch each face as you count. How many faces does it have?
levels.example_response: 6 faces. I touched the top, the bottom, the front, the back and both sides.
common_errors: Missing the bottom face because the shape is resting on it
Counting a face twice

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting faces, edges and vertices of 3-D shapes including cubes, cuboids and pyramids.
levels.example_task: Count the edges and vertices of this square-based pyramid.
levels.example_response: 8 edges and 5 vertices. 4 edges around the base and 4 going up to the top point.
common_errors: Confusing edges and vertices (saying the shape has 8 vertices instead of 5)
Missing edges at the base when the pyramid is sitting flat

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing and comparing 3-D shapes by their faces, edges and vertices, and sorting them by properties.
levels.example_task: Sort these shapes into two groups: those with all rectangular faces and those without. Name the shapes in each group.
levels.example_response: All rectangular faces: cube, cuboid. Not all rectangular: pyramid (has triangular faces), cylinder (has curved surface), triangular prism (has triangular and rectangular faces).
common_errors: Including the triangular prism in the 'all rectangular' group (forgetting the triangular end faces)
Not knowing whether a cube counts as having rectangular faces (squares are rectangles)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Pressing a face of a 3-D shape onto paper and identifying the 2-D shape it makes.
levels.example_task: Press the face of this cube onto the paper and trace around it. What shape did you draw?
levels.example_response: I drew a square. The face of a cube is a square.
common_errors: Drawing the whole 3-D shape instead of just one face
Not pressing flat enough and getting a distorted trace

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Naming all the 2-D face shapes on common 3-D shapes without tracing.
levels.example_task: What 2-D shapes can you see on a cylinder?
levels.example_response: Two circles (top and bottom) and a curved surface (which unrolls into a rectangle).
common_errors: Only identifying the circular faces and not mentioning the curved surface
Calling the curved surface 'a circle' because it is round

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying all face shapes on 3-D shapes and explaining how the 2-D shapes combine to form the 3-D shape.
levels.example_task: A triangular prism has faces that are different 2-D shapes. Name them and say how many of each.
levels.example_response: 2 triangles (the ends) and 3 rectangles (the sides). 5 faces in total.
common_errors: Saying '3 triangles and 2 rectangles' (swapping the counts)
Not knowing what a triangular prism looks like

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Distinguishing between moving in a straight line and turning on the spot using physical movement.
levels.example_task: Walk forwards 5 steps. Now stay in one spot and turn to face the window. Which was a straight line movement? Which was a turn?
levels.example_response: Walking was a straight line. Turning on the spot was a turn (rotation).
common_errors: Combining walking and turning into one movement
Not understanding that 'turning' means changing direction without moving forwards

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Making quarter, half and three-quarter turns and describing them as 1, 2 and 3 right angles.
levels.example_task: Face the door. Make a quarter turn clockwise. How many right angles did you turn?
levels.example_response: I turned 1 right angle. I am now facing the wall that was on my right.
common_errors: Confusing a quarter turn with a half turn
Not knowing the connection between 'quarter turn' and '1 right angle'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing rotations as whole, half, quarter or three-quarter turns in terms of right angles, clockwise or anticlockwise.
levels.example_task: I face North. I make 2 right angles clockwise. Which direction do I face? How many right angles is a full turn?
levels.example_response: I face South (2 right angles = half turn). A full turn is 4 right angles.
common_errors: Saying 2 right angles is a quarter turn
Not knowing that a full turn is 4 right angles

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Continuing a simple repeating pattern of shapes or colours given the first few elements.
levels.example_task: What comes next? Circle, square, circle, square, circle, ?
levels.example_response: Square. The pattern repeats: circle, square, circle, square.
common_errors: Repeating the last shape instead of continuing the pattern
Not identifying the repeating unit

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying the rule of a pattern with two or three changing attributes and continuing it.
levels.example_task: Continue this pattern: 5, 10, 15, 20, ?, ?
levels.example_response: 25, 30. The rule is 'add 5 each time'.
common_errors: Continuing with the wrong step size (adding 10 instead of 5)
Identifying the pattern by looking at only two consecutive terms

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing the rule of a pattern in words, creating their own patterns, and identifying errors in given patterns.
levels.example_task: This pattern has a mistake: 2, 4, 6, 8, 11, 12, 14. Find the mistake and correct it.
levels.example_response: The mistake is 11. It should be 10 because the pattern counts in 2s. The correct sequence is 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14.
common_errors: Not spotting the error and continuing the incorrect pattern
Identifying the error but not being able to state the correct value

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading a one-to-one pictogram where each picture represents one item.
levels.example_task: This pictogram shows favourite fruits. Each picture = 1 child. How many children chose apple?
levels.example_response: 4 children chose apple (there are 4 apple pictures).
common_errors: Counting the pictures for the wrong fruit
Miscounting when pictures are close together

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading a many-to-one pictogram (each symbol = 2 or 5) and constructing a simple block diagram from given data.
levels.example_task: Each star in this pictogram represents 2 children. The 'swimming' row has 4 stars. How many children chose swimming?
levels.example_response: 8 children. 4 stars × 2 = 8.
common_errors: Reading each symbol as 1 (saying 4 children instead of 8)
Not checking the key to find out what each symbol represents

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Interpreting and constructing pictograms, tally charts, block diagrams and tables, answering comparison and total questions.
levels.example_task: Draw a block diagram from this tally chart: Red 6, Blue 9, Green 3. Which colour was most popular? How many more blue than green?
levels.example_response: [Draws bars at correct heights] Blue was most popular with 9 votes. 9 – 3 = 6, so blue had 6 more than green.
common_errors: Drawing bars that do not match the data values
Answering 'how many more' by stating the larger number rather than the difference

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Answering 'how many' questions about data in a simple table or pictogram.
levels.example_task: Look at this table. How many children have a pet cat?
levels.example_response: 5 children have a pet cat.
common_errors: Reading the wrong row or column
Misreading the number in the table

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Answering 'which has most/least' and 'how many altogether' questions from charts and tables.
levels.example_task: Look at the block diagram. Which colour had the most votes? How many votes were there altogether?
levels.example_response: Blue had the most votes with 9. Altogether: 6 + 9 + 3 = 18 votes.
common_errors: Identifying the most popular category but unable to calculate the total
Adding incorrectly when finding the total

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Answering 'how many more/fewer' comparison questions and posing their own questions about data.
levels.example_task: Using this pictogram, how many more children like football than tennis? Write your own question about the data.
levels.example_response: 12 – 5 = 7. 7 more children like football than tennis. My question: 'How many children were asked altogether?'
common_errors: Answering 'how many more' by stating the larger number instead of the difference
Writing a question that cannot be answered from the data
